item.description:
Often compared to Mt. Monadnock Mt. Cardigan (3,155') offers 360 degree panaromic views at the summit. They are about the same elevation and they each had fires at the top that wiped out all of the trees and plant life. What's left behind is a bald summit with broad swaths of rock. At the summit you can expect plenty of ice and high winds.  

The forest and trails surrounding the area iniclude the Cardigan State Forest to the west and the AMC's 1,200 acre Cardigan Reservation to the east. With multiple peaks in this range several trail options exist. With an early sunset we'll  plan to summit Cardigan and move smartly onto Firescrew Mt and then down to the parking lot. Proposed route:

Manning Trail to Holt Trail to Holt-Clarke cut off to Clark Trail to the summit

Continue to Firescrew via Mowglis Trail then down via Manning Trail. Elevation gain: 1,700 feet. Round trip: 6 miles. Map: copy and paste link into your browser:

http://www.nhdfl.org/library/pdf/cardiganmap.pdf

Despite the mountain's modest elevation we can not underestimate the challenge of this hike. With ice and wind likely and snow forecast throughout the week full winter gear is mandatory for this hike. See equipment list below.

From I-93. Get off on Exit 24 and head west toward Bristol and proceed 6 miles until you reach the town center. Make a right onto Route 3A towards Plymouth. After about two miles make a left on at the Stone Church just before the lake. Go three mile past the crossroads and bear right about 3 mile from 3A. Three miles from there make a left. Take a right from the church and stay on the route until you reach the lodge.

 EQUIPMENT CHECKLIST
(gear must be winter weather tested)

Cold Weather/Winter Essentials (required):
• Synthetic or Wool Wicking Underpant & Undershirt
• Mid-layer Synthetic or Wool Insulating Pant & Shirt
• Insulated/Fleece Jacket and/or Vest
• Windproof/Waterproof Shell w/hood & Pant
• Synthetic or Wool Sock Liners (wicking layer)
• Synthetic or Wool Socks (insulating layer)
• Sturdy Hiking Boots (waterproof & insulated)
• Hat & Gloves
• Balaclava
• Goggles
• Extra Insulating Layers (pantalone & top)
• Extra pair of Socks, Hat & Gloves
• Water (min. 2L) - in a wide-mouthed bottle
• Snacks/Energy Food - Lunch
• Map/Compass/Whistle
• Headlamp/Flashlight (w/ fresh lithium batteries)
• Emergency Blanket (so small & light, there's no reason not to carry one)
• MICROspikes or more aggressive hiking crampons
• Snowshoes
• Gaiters

  • Trekking Poles (very helpful when using snowshoes)

    the Remaining Essentials:
    • Medication/First Aid Supplies*
    • Hand Warmers
    • Fire (waterproof matches, lighter, starter)
    • Repair Kit/Knife

    Optional:
    • Sunscreen/Sunglasses/Bug Repellent/Toiletries
    • Camera/Binoculars

    Miscellaneous
    Challenge/Pace: Moderate
    Sunset: 4:45p.m.

    Approx. High Temp: Mid 20's
    Approx. Low Temp: Low teens
